title: Nojimazaki Lighthouse
text:
is a <a href="lighthouse">lighthouse</a> located at the southern tip of the <a href="B%C5%8Ds%C5%8D%20Peninsula">Bōsō Peninsula</a>, in the city of <a href="Minamib%C5%8Ds%C5%8D%2C%20Chiba">Minamibōsō</a>, <a href="Chiba%20Prefecture">Chiba Prefecture</a> <a href="Japan">Japan</a>.
History.
The Nojimazaki Lighthouse was one of eight lighthouses to be built in <a href="Meiji%20period">Meiji period</a> Japan under the provisions of the <a href="Anglo-Japanese%20Treaty%20of%20Amity%20and%20Commerce">Anglo-Japanese Treaty of Amity and Commerce</a> of 1858, signed by the <a href="Bakumatsu%20period">Bakumatsu period</a> <a href="Tokugawa%20Shogunate">Tokugawa Shogunate</a>. The lighthouse was designed and constructed by <a href="o-yatoi%20gaikokujin">French engineer</a> <a href="L%C3%A9once%20Verny">Léonce Verny</a>, and is noteworthy in that it is the second lighthouse to be completed in Japan, after the <a href="Kannonzaki%20Lighthouse">Kannonzaki Lighthouse</a> on the opposing entrance to <a href="Tokyo%20Bay">Tokyo Bay</a>. As completed, the whitewashed octagonal brick structure stood high, and had a first-order <a href="Fresnel%20lens">Fresnel lens</a>, with a kerosene light source. The lighthouse was first lit on January 19, 1869.
During the <a href="1923%20Great%20Kant%C5%8D%20earthquake">1923 Great Kantō earthquake</a>, the top eight meters of the structure collapsed. It was rebuilt in concrete, and recommissioned on August 15, 1925. The structure was again damaged in 1945 by bombardment by the <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a>. It was repaired after the war with a second-order <a href="Fresnel%20lens">Fresnel lens</a>, and was subsequently electrified.
Current status.
The Nojimazaki Lighthouse is currently open to the public, who may visit a small museum at its base, and climb to the top for a panoramic view over the Pacific Ocean. It is registered with the <a href="International%20Association%20of%20Lighthouse%20Authorities">International Association of Lighthouse Authorities</a> as one of the “One Hundred Most Important Lighthouses in the World” and by the Japanese government as a Historic Monument.
